If you break down on a dual carriageway, how far away from your vehicle should you place a warning triangle?

16/1/2014

18 Comments

 
If you breakdown on a carriageway you should put a warning triangle on the road at least 45 metres (147 feet) behind your broken-down vehicle on the same side of the road, or use other permitted warning devices if you have them. Always take great care when placing or retrieving them, but never use them on motorways.

Jeremy Pritchard
1/8/2017 15:03:36

Picture shows a triangle of very poor quality, not worth using. Therefore, ensure the triangle you use complies to global Spec 'UNECE27R'. This has an efficient outer red reflex reflectors for night and fog use, and an inner fluroescent orange 'daytime' triangle.

The fold-out legs will be 'spidery', for resistance to wind buffeting, and may have rubber feet.

On a GB motorway, you could place it on the roof or boot - to increase the visual aspect of the scene to approaching traffic, your hazard-warning lights should be on, if functioning.

A triangle is placed to the 'side' of the affected lane, rather than its center, to allow movement away from it! In most countries placement can typically be 30-200m (steps) away from the scene. Ideal for rural roads, where curves, bends, twists etc render breakdowns and crash scenes invisible till the last second.

Use a high-vis vest on scene (EN 471 Class 2), if you have one. Don't take your eyes off approaching traffic when placing triangle/s, and only place IF it is safe to do so.

Where countries operate CB radio, use the recognised 'road channel' to alert traffic of breakdowns and crash scenes, useful to alert heavy vehicles for obvious reasons.

Stop to the side of the left-lane as far as possible - to allow other traffic to get through, or shoulder, and IF engine still operates, keep left indicator on. Fix those hazard lights. Buses et Al should carry three hazard warning triangles to UNECE 27R Spec. Placement is stamped on the packaging. Wear (and carry on board) a high visibility safety vest to EN471 Class 2. These are typically green fluorescent, and have light reflecting bands.

Jeremy Pritchard
7/12/2018 23:36:20

If a vehicle breaks down on a road or shoulder under any weather conditions, the driver should activate the vehicles hazard-warning lights.

Some countries permit the hazard warning lights to be routinely used when driving in poor visibility such as torrential rain or in heavy fog or dust storms. Owing safety concerns (complacency), I discourage at government level this action for moving vehicles. Better then, for nations to update vehicle standards and adopt as Mandatory the global design rule "UNECE 38" - Rear fog lamp function, for all vehicle and trailer categories. Education falls to the state, enforcement to police. This function is red in colour, and are purpose designed for low visibility driving, and means the hazard warning lights can be left for their original purpose; warning of a crash or breakdown. UN Convention on Road Traffic, permits drivers to give a 'quick' flash of hazard-warning lights, to signal to rear approaching traffic of danger up ahead, that they may not see. An example would be an unfolding crash around a curve or bend in the road, and you know you've got vehicles approaching your vehicle at speed. Done, to reduce likelihood of multi-family crash outcomes.
